para.sentence: The fundamental constant \pi=3.14159\;26535\;89793\;23846\;\ldot s can be defined analytically in numerous ways, for example, \pi=4\int_{0}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{1+t^{2}}.

Other constants that appear in the DLMF include the base e of natural logarithms e=2.71828\;18284\;59045\;23536\;\ldots\, , see §4.2(ii), and Euler’s constant \gamma \gamma=0.57721\;56649\;01532\;86060\;\ldots , see §5.2(ii).
For access to online high-precision numerical values of mathematical constants seeSloane (2003).
For historical and other information see Finch (2003).
